head.title: How to Juice Up Fruit Compote

hedline.hl1: How to Juice Up Fruit Compote

abstract.p: Comment on use of jujube fruit in Chinese and Indian cooking; photo (S)

block.p: To American moviegoers, a jujube is the colorful jellylike candy that sticks to your teeth. But a jujube is also a smooth-skinned, walnut-size subtropical fruit that is used in Chinese and Indian cooking.

For the interested shopper, Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street) is selling fresh jujubes for $8 a pound (about 20). When green they are quite firm, and the pale, somewhat mealy flesh suggests a slightly astringent apple. As they ripen, they turn a rusty color and become sweeter. They're usually dried and used in desserts. Chinese groceries sell the dried ones, sometimes labeled ''red dates.''

To American moviegoers, a jujube is the colorful jellylike candy that sticks to your teeth. But a jujube is also a smooth-skinned, walnut-size subtropical fruit that is used in Chinese and Indian cooking.

For the interested shopper, Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street) is selling fresh jujubes for $8 a pound (about 20). When green they are quite firm, and the pale, somewhat mealy flesh suggests a slightly astringent apple. As they ripen, they turn a rusty color and become sweeter. They're usually dried and used in desserts. Chinese groceries sell the dried ones, sometimes labeled ''red dates.''

Too impatient to wait until they ripened and shriveled, I simmered a pound of fresh jujubes in two cups of water with a half cup of sugar, a two-inch piece of vanilla bean and 10 whole cloves for 30 minutes, then let them cool in the syrup overnight. They became mellow and tender, a curiosity to add to a fruit compote or to serve alongside roast pork -- but not to take to the movies.
